title: Can I get a patent for something that doesn't do anything? - Quora
tags: Legal Issues and Law in Everyday Life

response.answer_text: No, you cannot obtain a utility patent for something that has no use. If you applied for a utility patent for this non-useful thing, the patent examiner ought to reject the application under 35 USC section 101. You could, however, possibly obtain a design patent, which protects the look (design) of the thing. With a design patent, you can merely stop others from making or selling goods that look like yours. But for a non-useful product, that might be exactly the kind of patent protection you'd want.

Like a pet rock? The patent system is designed to promote the “useful arts”. Thus, there is a “utility” requirement for patent eligibility. As a practical matter, this requirement rarely comes into play because very few people try to patent things that are not useful (and there usually is not a market for them anyway). It comes up in the chemistry area most often - since it is easy to create new chemicals that have no known use. We don’t want people patenting them just in case someone later figures out a use. People that later figure out a use can patent that use, even though they can’t patent the chemical itself if they did not invent it.

No I doubt it. Three things are necessary in order to get a patent; it must be novel. Nothing like it may ever have existed before. Ever.It must be inventive. It cannot be a step away from another idea that would be common sense.3. It must have commercial application. An example of its commercial use must be included in the patent. An item that does not do anything will not have a commercial application.

If an invention has no utility, it is not a proper subject for patenting. “Utility” is defined rather broadly - a patentable invention must be generally useful and it must have a specific utility. Note that “for purpose of amusement” is a true utility, so an invention that is just silly might very well be patentable. But an invention that does absolutely NOTHING cannot be patented. Why SHOULD such an invention be patented?
